entries.name: Age
entries: Graftlings do not age. They are sustained by the magic that created them.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Graftling alignment is similar to their identity in life, but may have been influenced by their transformation. Whatever the case, graftlings are reclusive, and tend toward a neutral alignment.

entries.name: Size
entries: Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Undead
entries: You are undead. You don't require air, food, drink, or sleep. A long rest amounts to four hours in an inactive but conscious state.

entries.name: Graftling Physiology
entries: Your skeleton is receptive to further perversion. By taking the ten minutes necessary to fully attach and adjust, you can graft *purely decorative* bones anywhere on your body. Additionally, so long as it has bones, you have the option to graft the arm of a creature no larger than you and it becomes functional. You may only have one limb attached in this manner at any given time, and may remove it at will.

items: If your extra limb is empty or already holding the object, you can Use an Object as a bonus action, or interact with a second object as part of your free action.
If two of your arms are being used to wield weaponry, you can't benefit from the AC bonus of a shield, or any abilities that require one.

entries.name: Bone App√©tit
entries: You hunger for bones and can consume them to regain your strength. As a bonus action, you may consume a bone of a size no smaller than the finger of a Medium creature to regain hit points equal to 1d10 + your Constitution modifier + your level. You may choose to detach and consume your extra limb in this manner. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Marrowsense
entries: You have a nose for marrow. You have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that involve smell to sense creatures or objects containing bone. In addition to any other result, a successful check imparts knowledge of the creature type to which the bone belongs or belonged.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and one language you knew in life.

{@italic An unimposing bundle waits wordlessly while the mercenaries gathered around discuss their next move. She shifts her weight uncomfortably, bones clinking, when their leader silences the group with a raised palm and gives her an expectant look. The graftling coils her third arm tighter around her torso. She inhales, concentrates.}

{@italic The skeletons of her party all reek in their own unique way. A pair of recently-caught pheasants dangle from the hunter's pack. He's secreted a third for himself. A cloister of skrimshaw dice sit in a pouch belonging to their cleric. She doesn't like that he plays with her food. A nightjar darts through the forest. She can just make out the marrow wafting from a corpse somewhere beyond the farthest reaches of her senses.}
{@italic They are alone. She shakes her head, and the leader presses on.}

entries.name: Bred to the Bone
entries: A miserable pile of assorted bones. Graftlings are corpses who have had their skeletons transformed, grafted with those of other creatures, and infused with negative energy. They are given teeth with which to extract and pulverize bone, corrosive digestive fluids to break down and assimilate it, and the hunger to consume it. How closely a graftling resembles its original race is up to the whim of its creator, but because graftlings are the product of transplantation rather than total reconstruction, there is generally some resemblance. All graftlings end up a perversion of the skeleton.

There are reasons beyond simple experimentation that might inspire a necromancer to create a graftling. Due to their intelligence and reserved disposition, graftlings make practical, less ambitious apprentices. What's more, what was once a miserable pile of assorted bones can now dispose of any unwanted miserable piles of assorted bones. While graftlings often emerge with their intelligence intact, the same cannot always be said for their identity. All find that some part of their past self is invariably corrupted in the process.

entries.name: A Bone to Pick
entries: Not all bones are created equal. The bones of a kobold might be greasy; those of a cambion might be spicy. A graftling may prefer a certain type of bone, or outright ignore others.

entries.name: Bottom Feeder
entries: Unlike many undead, graftlings aren't made to be predators. They don't hunt the living. They are vultures of the battlefield; they haunt pillaged hamlets; they feast upon ossuaries. They scavenge. If a person needs to worry about a graftling, that person is already dead. Graftlings will avoid fighting for corpses, preferring caution to a meal for which they hunger but do not need.

Graftlings who find themselves in the wild take refuge in the corners of the world dark enough to avoid others, but close enough to life to smell a corpse on the wind. They prefer to lead solitary lives. However, this predilection doesn't erase the personality they had in life—provided reanimation didn't do that much. Consider graftling character an issue of nature vs. nurture vs. nature.

entries.name: Reluctant But Willing
entries: A graftling's disposition does not make them immune to wanderlust; it only dampens the desire. The call to travel might come from the memories of a life lost. Maybe they seek to exact revenge on their murderer. Maybe they want to confront their creator. Maybe they wish for more than mere survival. The reasons a graftling would set out are as numerous and varied as any character.

Those who grow restless enough to venture into civilization must tread lightly, and dress heavily. Undead are feared if not hated, so discovery could very well mean death. How well a graftling adjusts to civilization depends in part on the personality they had in life, in part on their willpower and discretion.

entries.name: Bundle Up
entries: Graftlings would do well to keep their figure in mind when outfitting. Heavy, loose-fitting clothing goes a long way in concealing their odd bone structure. Illusions, masks, and disguise kits are tools with a place in any graftling's repertoire.

entries.name: Graftling Names
entries: Graftlings will use the name they had in life, unless they've forgotten it or chosen to forsake a past to which they no longer belong. In either case, they'll assume the name given to them by their creator, if given one, or choose a name that appeals to them.
Graftling Names: Chirr, Skrim, Skel, Odokuro, Smelch, Nyargh, Zailofon, Urk, Kvetch, Slummock, Rote, Huam, Scroop, Fyerk, Caret, Kashl, Callus, Pelops, Clak, Ahki, Mort, Sistrum

entries.caption: Graftling Reasons for Adventure
rows: Targeted by a monster slayer, you were forced to flee your home.
You seek justice for your creator, who showed you compassion but was slain by adventurers.
Haunted by the memories of your past life, you wish to reconcile or reunite.
You've no intention of squandering your second chance at life on the fringes of civilization.
You figure you'll try your hand at archaeology.
You have slain your creator, and are pursued by their enclave.
Your apprenticeship ended without consequence, and you were permitted to leave your master.
You're awful at direction, and keep stumbling into civilization.
You were dispatched by your master to complete an errand or quest.
You will assimilate all other graftlings. There can be only one.

entries.caption: Graftling Quirks
rows: Your reanimation was so traumatizing you've developed an irrational fear of bones.
You think skeletons are cute because of the way they are.
You prefer to hide during a fight.
You painstakingly log the bones you have encountered.
You've developed a nightly ritual of snorting bone meal.
Your body is a collection that you embellish with only the rarest bones.
You're incredibly awkward.
You have obsessive tendencies.
You have a habit of sidling up to others to get a whiff of their skeleton.
You treat your bundle as a refuge. Even those close to you haven't seen your face.

entries.caption: Graftling Trinkets
rows: An innocuous mortar and pestle engraved with the initials of your creator.
A trinket from your past life ({@italic see any other {@item trinket (phb)|phb|trinket} table}).
A mysterious bone that defies all attempts at identification.
A tiny, wooden, unfortunate cat figure.
A vial of bubbling rainbow-colored neutralizer.
A pair of rusty manacles.
A cuneiform-incised pebble that once belonged to a lost child.
A jar containing a misshapen mass preserved in formaldehyde.
A set of scrimshaw dice that sometimes emit whale song.
A grimy skull extracted from the necromancer who reanimated you.
A twisted blackwood broom with bristles that never dirty.
A dragon-shaped pin that can be tracked by someone, somewhere.
A beckoning throw pillow embroidered with the shifting image of a paddling duck.
A brackish collar that makes its wearer feel wanted.
A tattooed arm of a grung that was boiled alive.
A smelt skeleton that flutters in stagnant water.
A runed notebook with scrawled notes on undead.
A hefty roll of ghoul flesh secured with twine.
A pouch of multi-colored, skeleton-shaped gelatin sweets.
A signet ring bearing a serpent-entwined rod of inlaid glass.
